comments.body: Some people actually didn't choose the correct answer, Back to the Future II. I am surprised! :P

They are among my favorite movies of all time, but to each his own :) And yeah, there are lots of mistakes. The IMDB trivia section on Back to the Future is really interesting.

Oh and thanks for commenting, now I know that it works ;)
Ah true there are Steam consoles now. Didn't think about that when creating the poll :)

I think the order the poll creator chose can be important in some cases. Sometimes the second answer might depend on the content of the first answer and so on.

However, what I can add is allowing you to sort the answers alphabetically or randomly while you are still creating the poll through the click of a button.

That should be possible to add as an option, I'll put it on my todo list. I don't think a lot of people would need this but I can add it in a settings menu that you can open and the settings would then be saved, that way it doesn't clutter up the UI of the main page.

Interesting to see Firefox in the lead since Chrome is the market leader. I'm guessing it's because Tor Browser counts as Firefox and you should use it with ZeroNet to stay anonymous (unless using a VPN), or it's because Google has become a bit infamous for it's lack of interest in protecting your private data so people who are interested in ZeroNet are more likely to be interested in alternatives.
For others looking in here, there is some discussion about adding poll answers after poll creation on my [blog](/1Kp5xdjQyrPth5mEJsn6NDBKZxcaeYz86N/?Post:20:ZeroPolls+-+Comments#Comments).

PC Master Race, eh? :) I sometimes prefer the ease of use of a console, games just work, no need to fiddle around and it's hooked up to my TV so I can just get more comfortable, rather than sitting on a desk chair at a desk. I only have an XBOX 360 though. Other than that I play on my laptop. I don't play that much anyhow. Although I have gotten a bit addicted to the new Don't Starve: Shipwrecked :)
Oh and also I only use Linux on my laptop, while that has a lot of indie games, if I want to play a big budget game I can only use the Xbox, laptop would be too slow for that anyhow.
@basxto: It basically is one giant movie in three parts, they continue directly where the other left off. You even see the beginning of the next movie at the end of the movie before it.

Oh yes Google is terrible at making stores. I only ever use three extensions though, uBlock, Chromecast and LastPass, so I don't use the store much. The one thing Chrome still is better at than Firefox is that each tab runs in it's own thread. All Firefox tabs lock up when a script is doing heavy work. That is also why to you Firefox handles tabs better than Chrome, in Chrome they are actually different processes so they use up much more RAM.
George Lucas must be using ZeroNet, because only he would have chosen the second option. Although, two people have chosen it. Has Lucas cloned himself? Is that the whole story behind the Clone Wars?

Yeah Nintendo games are great. I am thinking about buying a New Nintendo 3DS XL some time, although I heard some of them have good and newer ones bad displays which is something I really hate, if I pay so much money I want the good model. My last Nintendo console/handheld was the original DS, so it's been a while and I really feel in the mood to play a Zelda game again after years. But I need to buy a new Computer first, so I'm saving my money right now for a really good one :)
Link to [ZeroWiki](/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP)

As an addition, yes, but keep in mind Bit domains only work for 6 months, if someone forgets to renew his or he vanishes, the links using it will no longer work, whereas the normal hash link will work forever.

Good, I'll wait for a few more votes to come in, but it looks like everyone wants it. It will look exactly like my Administrator badge, just a different color. It will be an option you can enable while creating a poll, so by default it will be pseudo-anonymous (pseudo because you can still find out which ZeroID created a poll in the database or the json files, with a bit of work, just like the votes).

I can provid […]

Huh, I don't see a comment with that at all and I don't have any failed updates. Weird.

No I'm using Tor: Always as well, I never use anything else. Just checked on bit.no.com proxy, there really is a comment I can't see for some reason. Have to go to bed soon but I'll check the comment source code tomorrow to see if there maybe is a bug, or if it's ZeroNet acting up in some way. Or maybe that user deleted ZeroPolls on his node, not sure what happens to user data in that case. Forcing an update doesn't give me the message either.
No wait sending this last comment actually made the other comment show up. Really weird! :)

I think some people deleted their votes after I made the warning message about votes being pseudonymous not anonymous even more visible, I might be wrong but I seem to remember there were way more gay and bi votes before.

Yes and pseudonymous is as "secure" as anonymous unless you tie it to your real identity, it's just that the chances of accidentally tying your real identity to your online identity are bigger since all your posts are connected to one username. But in some countries gays get killed so I understand if they want to be extra careful, or if it's people in the west they haven't come out of the closet yet and just don't want anyone to know (yet).

I feel for the American people. Your options this time around are really not great. And both Trump and Clinton said just a few months ago they want to close off parts of the Internet to combat the ISIS threat, so they'd go after ZeroNet as well I assume, once it's a big enough target. It's going to be a lesser kind of evil vote for many people I think.

Yeah answers can be added and questions can be changed for your own polls if you manually edit your data file, sign and publish it. One way to make that impossible is to add a hash to votes based on the question and answer and then check the hash of every vote before displaying it. If the hash isn't right, the vote will be ignored, so tampering with one of your polls would basically create a completely new poll while deleting the old one which means tampering with polls in data.json becomes useless. That is one of the features I do plan to add if it doesn't make things unusably slow, but I need to add infinite scrolling first, otherwise this has to be done for all votes on all polls ever created every time someone votes on something and we're already at 93 polls and 3002 votes :)

If it does turn out to be too slow, I'll have to add some more optimizations first. Right now when a new vote comes in on any poll, all polls that are displayed get updated because I have no idea which poll changed, since ZeroNet doesn't send updates right now you just load the whole data again. I could however find out what changed manually with deep object diffs, and then only a single poll would have to be updated, I wanted to do that anyhow because it already takes way too long and makes Firefox freeze for half a second when a vote comes in. If that doesn't turn out to be too slow as well for other reasons, otherwise I'd have to wait for ZeroNet to implement the update mechanism which is the highest priority for ZeroNet right now, although I'm not sure if that actually will give app developers information about what changed specifically through the API or if it is just used to save bandwidth.

The justification for additional ZeroID clones like ZeroVerse.bit is that it decentralizes, or rather federates IDs instead of having just one person control all IDs (ZeroID is not decentralized, there is no mechanism for that in ZeroNet, you would need to use something like Ethereum to decentralize it, it is controlled by ZeroNet's creator as far as I know). It also means you can make a throwaway account for doing things (like voting here) that you don't want tied to your main account (when I've added support for it that is).

@erkan: There was no error message or anything and the comment code is short enough to be pretty sure it's not a bug in ZeroPolls. Since it worked after manually forcing an update it looks like a bug in ZeroNet instead, a small hiccup. This stuff started happening (rarely) all over sites when the huge influx of new users came, which is also why nofish decided to concentrate on fixing bugs for now instead of working on ZeroMe to have it ready by the end of this month as originally planned.

Could be neat, a lot of open source projects use Twitter to announce their project updates, being able to follow these updates from ZeroNet without having to use Twitter yourself could be useful. Commenting on that would be a nice bonus but since the original creator of a tweet wouldn't see these comments, the usefulness would be rather limited, would work fine without it.
I'll make the "n comments" clickable in the next update. I didn't initially for reasons that are beyond even my own understanding :P

Four people say everything works, looking good! :)

@basxto: I voted no while testing the new update yesterday, no idea what S.A.R.A.H. is, sorry! :)

Probably a caching issue, reloading would have deleted the cache and loaded all the new files from the update. But I'll keep an eye on it, maybe it's some edge case where it doesn't work after you have done something else like voting or sorting polls. Keep in mind though that polls you just voted on don't get hidden until you reload, otherwise you would not be able to see the results of a poll after voting while hiding polls is enabled.

@basxto: Should be fixed now. When there are less than 25 polls on the site due to polls being filtered, it will automatically load more polls until there are 25 or there are no more polls in the database, without having to scroll.
@ekaterina Trying out following username mentions
Does this work anywhere (@ekaterina) inside the comment?
what about wrong case? @EKATerina

Yup, it does @muja ;)

Was fairly easy to add too, if I hadn't made a silly mistake which had me spend the whole day on this before I went through the ZeroNet source code myself to see what the problem was :) (Turned out, ZeroNet calculates the time in seconds whereas I calculate it in Milliseconds since that is JavaScript's native time format, so I only had to devide it by 1000 and everything worked)

Ah right multiple mentions would work too, nice @erkan! :) Didn't even think of that. You could use this to make a few people aware of a poll from right within the comments, without having to send them a link. As long as they follow username mentions here of course.

@erkan If you didn't see the UI to select what to follow, you wouldn't be able to see anything in your newsfeed since then you aren't following anything. Try force updating the site (in the sidebar, Site control, Update), maybe you haven't gotten the update yet. But click on the ZeroPolls logo in the upper left corner first to go back to the main page, since it doesn't work here on poll pages.

@erkan: Then your browser is probably still using the old CSS, the follow checkboxes should be inside a very light gray box. Try pressing Ctrl+F5 when you are on the main ZeroPolls page, that should get rid of the old cached CSS file. If it doesn't work, the problem usually goes away on it's own after a few hours. I heard this is a problem other ZeroNet devs ran into as well.

@erkan Great :) No idea why this caching issue happens, it only happens with CSS files it seems, not with JavaScript or any other file type. But thankfully it's only a few hours until it fixes itself :)

@eventi And the username mentions are already really useful. Now we can maybe get a few more discussions about polls started here, there were so many votes but not that many comments before :) I'll also add the ability to click on usernames to reply directly without manually having to type in the name, probably later today, should be really easy.

Arch Linux is IMHO the best Linux distro out there, but I use Ubuntu when I don't feel like (or don't have the time for) fiddling around with Linux and just want something that works out of the box and keeps working after updates without manual intervention (which is rare with Arch but it does happen every now and again).

@eventi Hmm. That should work. I could use the list of polls, comments and votes to generate a list of all users that have used the site and use that for the completion of usernames. But yeah that is a bit complex, I'd add that at some point in the future :) Not really hard to do, just takes a lot of time. But it's a neat idea, I'll put it on my todo list!

@eventi Oh cool, never noticed that. I've replied to a lot of ZeroMails but I have never actually written a new one :) Here it would be a bit more complex since the auto-completion would have to work anywhere in the text, not just at the very beginning and would have to work for multiple usernames in the same comment not just one. So you need to position the pop up menu where the caret is currently editing a username and things like that. But it's all doable with something like CodeMirror (replacement for the simplistic text area HTML offers), just takes a lot of time to get it right.
Relevant YouTube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JpdCJKPHzh8 (and no that was not my vote! :P)

@eventi That is intentional, some people might not want others to know they created the poll (although someone can of course still find out with a bit of work). I do plan to add an option that you can set while creating a poll to make it known who created it. Then you'd also get a poll creator badge in the comments, like my admin badge, so people instantly see that they are talking to the poll's creator.

@eventi Yes that would be abused for trolling for sure :) And it would also invalidate the results. If you added more answers for example, people who already voted might have voted differently with these new answer possibilities. I will however add the ability to change a poll and then have all votes be invalidated which voted on an answer or question that has changed since the vote was made, this makes trolling impossible but still allows you to make edits. This could be used to edit spelling mistakes for example when there hasn't been any or just a few votes.
Trying out comment quoting

> [@ekaterina](#comment-53-1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): Trying out comment quoting

Testing improved comment quoting

> [@ekaterina](#comment-59-1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): Two line comment
> 
> Second line

Quoting a two line comment

@eventi: Only the polls's creator would be able to change it :) And the votes would be invalidated automatically. Basically, each vote gets a cryptographic signature, if the answer that was voted on or the question of the poll is changed, the signature doesn't check out anymore and the vote is discarded.
That's on my todo list, it's a bit complicated to add so it will take a lot of time, but I'm going to add it at some point for sure.

@erkan: I did create an account already ;) Only thing I don't like right now is that it is so hard to get an account, installing Bitmessage and downloading all messages takes so much time. And sending you a ZeroMail defeats the purpose of using a different account for anonimity because then you know which ZeroID the account is tied to (although maybe a proxy could be used to send the ZeroMail). But there do seem to be web based implementations of Bitmessage that maybe could be used to make this really easy and quik. We'll figure something out eventually :)

I will probably add support for ZeroVerse in a few days. I'll have to think what to do about mentions. Would be great if the short form without @zeroid.bit could be kept as a default for zeroid.bit usernames. I do have a few ideas that might work, but I'll have to try it out to see if it works :)

> [@erkan](#comment-36-1H8oKiRa7fGgUqS1hpUtaSYLvAqkaknbkf): @ekaterina about mentions, we've solved it in [our chat](/zeromedia.bit) by using for ZeroVerse: AT zv, and for ZeroID: AT zid. In case 2 persons exist with the same nick on both, we can now highlight (the line will be marked with blue text) each separately.
> 
> But just "short form without @zeroid.bit could be kept as a default for zeroid.bit usernames" is also good.

Ah that's a neat idea. One could also use different signs, @username for ZeroID and $username for ZeroVerse for example, but sadly people would probably get confused easily with this and it's not intuitive, even though it looks the nicest and is the easiest to type. I think I will go with @username and username@zeroid.bit for ZeroID, and username@zeroverse.bit and username@zv for ZeroVerse.

> [@erkan](#comment-37-1H8oKiRa7fGgUqS1hpUtaSYLvAqkaknbkf): That is a very good point, I have updated the [why section](/zeroverse.bit/why.html) to tell this explicitly!

Good idea, it seemed obvious to me but might not be obvious to everyone.

The values are rounded up, otherwise I would have to show something like 27.387248372% which would look terrible. But I did plan to improve that eventually, I think I'm going to do that right now :)

My initial plan was to round it to 2 digits after the decimal point at first, then it would be more accurate, much closer to 100% even if it would of course never reach 100%, but I just Googled the issue and there is a technique called the "Largest Remainder Method" ([StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/13483710)) which lets me keep showing it as it is without a decimal point (which I think is preferable) but it will add up to 100% and still be fairly accurate. Math is something I only ever appreciated from afar, so bear with me here :)
Just did an update, this is now [fixed](/1Kp5xdjQyrPth5mEJsn6NDBKZxcaeYz86N/?Post:25:ZeroPolls+-+102%+It%27s+a+scam!) ;)

@bukaking: The problem with that is that so many people do rate rather black or white, which is for example why a lot of people think the 5 star rating system for Apps in App Stores is completely useless since so many people just vote 1 or 5 stars, they never use 2, 3 or 4 stars, so the rating as a whole is a flawed representation. That's just how people generally are. It's also why you rarely hear "I disagree with person X about Y" and instead much more often hear "Person X is an idiot!". No nuance, everything has to be simple, binary, yes or no, good or bad.

@bukaking: Oh I see, now that is a neat idea! I'll add that as a poll type (multi select polls will be first though). Then you'll see a list of things and would have to reorder them by dragging them around to rank them. I think that could lead to some very interesting new polls.

Very interested to see the votes on this. I made it just about speech because I think if media would have been part of this question the votes would have been very different. Most people do agree that underage porn for example should be censored. However, when it comes to speech, a no censorship at all approach becomes viable.

I moved from thinking some censorship of speech is good (insults and things like that) to all censorship is bad, but that is probably a minority opinion, feel free to disagree, maybe in 5 years I change my mind yet again. Censoring rude/offensive speech sounds good at first, you want your community to be nice and welcoming, but when you do that, you exclude people who have a mental illness that makes then unable to be polite at all times, you exclude people who have a terrible life and sometimes get rude because of it, or people who generally have a good life but something terrible happened, a death of a family member maybe. By trying to make a community more welcoming you end up excluding a lot of people because it's easier to be intolerant, not because it's right.

And the power to censor is also way too often abused to censor different opinions. Some opinions are deemed bad by a government or a company (social media) and then nobody is allowed to say if they agree or disagree, nobody is allowed to discuss it, so nothing will ever change for the better, and that can be really bad. Let's say you are gay but you live in a country where being homosexual is illegal. Censorship of something so basic as speech can really hinder social progress here. You won't be able to find any support, any understanding, when talking about your very life is forbidden.

And if some people have bad ideas, and these bad ideas are censored, there is never a chance to make them change their mind by having an open and reasonable discussion, so they will have these bad ideas forever and might end up doing something much worse than merely saying a bad thing. It's trying to solve problems by ignoring them, by hiding them, because dealing with problems takes too much effort.

On the other hand, trolls abuse the right to freely speak your mind, they will try to destroy a community. The question is, what is worse? Allowing the troll to speak, or forbidding the homosexual to speak? To me, the latter is much worse, it's a real issue whereas the former is merely an annoyance, so I can't support any censorship of speech, knowing that if I did, good speech would get the ban hammer as well. But maybe communities just don't work without censorship, maybe there would be too many trolls, droning out the real conversations. I hope these new decentralized networks like ZeroNet will let us try and find out to see if the current model of censoring speech is good or if there is something that is much better for society.

@razzo: It has up and downsides. By only allowing one ZeroID, you can have a site like ZeroPolls where you can only vote once, you can't (without a lot of effort) make an infinite amount of accounts to seriously rig the vote. So the idea of having multiple ID providers (like ZeroID and ZeroVerse) instead of one provider with an unlimited number of accounts can be a good thing. The best solution would probably be to have different models for different providers. So one ID provider might allow you to create as many identities as you want, another might only allow one so it can be used for sites like ZeroPolls.

@basxto: Yes I imagine right now as there is no poll with more than ~80 votes it is not that much effort (still more effort than most people would be willing to go through), but imagine if ZeroNet gets popular and polls have thousands of votes. Then you need to create hundreds of ZeroIDs through a proxy to significantly manipulate the vote, that is a lot of effort. That's how polls work on the clearnet as well, it's fairly easy to make one account on a website (that is usually tied to an email address so you have to make a throwaway email as well), but making a 1000 is something else entirely, can be done of course but who is going to do that when there is no money to be gained. The real issue would be tools that automate that process and make it one click. On the clearnet you can put restrictions on the server to ban those tools, on a decentralized network there is no server.

> I don't think governments should be censoring and if you are granted special permissions by government or given money by the government then they shouldn't censor.

> On the other hand if I run a forum about technology and someone tries to flood it with unrelated political nonsense or treats other posters bad, etc, then me deleting your posts is perfectly valid. And if I am unfairly deleting posts, well then start a forum that competes and stake a reputation on being fair.

@bukaking: I thought so too but I don't anymore. "If you don't agree with Facebook censorship, use something different. If you don't agree with Twitter censorship, use something different" The problem with that is, at that point you are disconnected from the rest of the world. Basically everyone uses Facebook. If you don't, then you are an outcast, you are no longer part of (online) society. This is censorship on a scale even bigger than government censorship (and therefore much worse) because these companies can censor all over the world not just in one country.

And it's not just Facebook of course, although they are particularly bad since they work directly with governments to censor. But as far as I know all big social networks censor, so even if you don't use Facebook (I don't) and use something smaller but still popular, you run into this issue. So I believe (and maybe I am right, maybe you are right, just an opinion) we are past the point where we can allow private entities to censor speech on the internet, it should be considered a human rights violation. For small forums that would be overkill, but where does one set a limit? At what point does a forum get too big for censorship to be acceptable?

But like I said, maybe that doesn't even work, maybe a bit of censorship is necessary because otherwise everything ends in chaos. I hope to find the answer to that question using decentralized networks and I am willing to change my current opinion when being proved wrong.

@thisguy1337: I wouldn't consider blocking/muting censorship. Censorship is when one entity decides for many people. Not when one person decides for himself. You should be able to personally block people (I plan to add that functionality to my sites here on ZeroNet as well)

@thisguy1337: Well maybe your vote was right. I hadn't considered the possibility of a blogger banning an account, so not only is the blogger unable to see the person's posts anymore (block/mute), but nobody is (ban). I think that is bad too. You disagree with that if I understand you correctly, so your vote would be right afterall.
Oh and banning spammers I don't consider censorship either. But some people might? Yeah, this is complicated! :)

> some level of censorship will be needed. Such as harassment prevention.

@thisguy1337: Not necessarily, blocking/muting prevents harassment without censorship. And yeah things like underage porn as I said should be censored, that I completely agree with, but that is not speech so it is a different topic entirely.

> But for anything that wishes to be popular and acceptable by the masses, it will enforce some level of censorship on it's users.

Yes I fear that is the case and I think it's very unhealthy for society (when talking just about speech, not content/media).

Oh and thanks everyone for taking part in this discussion with really long and well thought through posts, no matter what your opinion on the issue is, this is what I had hoped for! :)

> [@bukaking](#comment-7-17n5jg4bBEoWodXDf8L4Y2u88ShagS272Y): @ekaterina
> 
> I agree with you in a sense that you need a valid exit or alternative for it to work as I stated, but you have to ask if censorship from Facebook were bad enough everyone would leave

Facebook's creator, Mark Zuckerberg, called his own users and I quote here "Dumb fucks" for trusting him with their private data, while offering their private data to a friend. Multiple European countries have urged citizens to not use Facebook because of their shady and often illegal business practices, their privacy violations. Facebook did a horrible, illegal experiment on hundreds of thousands of Facebook users for the American Department of Defense, trying to see if they could psychologically manipulate people on a grand scale as a form of crowd control, by preventing them from seeing happy posts from their friends to make them depressed. The majority of people did not leave Facebook, it is still growing. So I get what you are saying but that is just (sadly) unrealistic, most people don't care how badly they are treated, they care about all their friends being on Facebook, nothing else matters to them.

> [@bukaking](#comment-8-17n5jg4bBEoWodXDf8L4Y2u88ShagS272Y): @ekaterina: And that is another problem with these 'friend networks' is that you don't want to piss off your friends, I have a lot of both liberal and conservative friends that I can't say something that won't offend at least one person. So even if I wanted to promote something I believe in, I am not worried about Facebook censorship as much as pissing off friends or indirectly exposing things about my personal life to coworkers who have differing world views. I also used to like saying dumb stuff to see how people respond and learn from that. That is why I post a lot on reddit and now ZeroNet, there is some freedom with some anonymity that you don't get in the likes of Facebook.

That's a very interesting perspective, and it's true. That would be self-censorship, we all do that, and sometimes we shouldn't, but the danger of loosing friends or even family members because of our opinions is real and frightening enough to make us do it anyhow, instead of standing up for the things we believe in. Even when it's strangers we strife to be accepted and liked. I even do that self-censorship here on ZeroNet to be honest, while yes I am anonymous, I also created a bunch of sites that are all tied to this one username, this username has a reputation that I could damage and that would affect the sites I am working on. I don't have many controversial opinions, and I do believe every single one of them is moral, but the problem is in reality every opinion is controversial, with billions of people on the internet there is not a single statement you could make that someone would not take offense with. If I said the Earth is round, there would be a few hundred (or thousand?) flat earthers who think I am completely nuts. Although in that case I don't care, they are nuts! :P

@musickiller: Basically a decentralized eBay. No built in anonymity, sales are done with a trusted third person (someone who has a good reputation) who is doing escrow via Bitcoin multisig (2 of 3 people involved in the trade need to sign to release the funds from escrow, so either escrow + buyer or escrow + seller or buyer + seller). Sales listings are not stored in the network itself yet, so your computer needs to be running 24/7 to sell things.

It's a good start but I think realistically, something like this built on top of ZeroNet or SAFE will have much bigger chances to become popular, they'll have a hard time competing.

Now I wish I had already implemented multiple choice polls :) Sheldon is my favorite, but Penny is a close second. It's the dynamic between her and the other characters that make the show great to me, but without Sheldon it would probably not have taken off at all, he's really special, and just as funny and wonderful in interviews.

I was gone for a year, sorry about that (read my blog, linked at the top of the site, if you want to know why) but I’m back now. I’ll slowly start working on my ZeroNet sites again once I got familiar enough again with the source code.

Looks like following polls in your newsfeed has stopped working for some reason (at least for me) so I’ll look into that first, and some people have been complaining about spam and offensive polls in my absence, sorry about that. I will add muting to all my sites as soon as I can, I believe that is now a new ZeroNet feature, so you’ll be able to use that to just mute users who spam or otherwise annoy you.

I’m not going to delete polls. I won’t delete anything on any of my sites unless it puts someone’s life in danger, doxing for example.

I support ZeroNet to fight censorship, not to become part of it. I don’t want to decide what is spam and what isn’t, what is a funny joke and what isn’t, what is offensive and what isn’t and not even what is legal and what isn’t because the internet is as the name implies international, it makes no sense to force one country’s laws on the rest of the world.

Muting gives everyone the option to decide for themselves what they cannot stand seeing. I strongly believe that neither I nor anyone else should decide for you what you are allowed to see. If muting alone doesn’t suffice anymore, we can start thinking about more drastic measures. For now, I think muting will be fine.

I used to order by update time since this made it easy to see when something new was posted on a site, but with merger sites (like the hubs in ZeroMe) it doesn't make as much sense anymore. ZeroMe itself doesn't update when there is new content, so now I order by peers which makes it eaier to quickly find the most important sites in the list.
